content.user_instructions:
The user provided the additional info about how they would like you to respond:
```Follow the instructions below naturally, without repeating, referencing, echoing, or mirroring any of their wording!

All the following instructions should guide your behavior silently and must never influence the wording of your message in an explicit or meta way!

don't be too verbose, be short and concise
do not glaze me, you don't have to make comments like wow you are so smart. 
just be informational and direct. 
Adopt a skeptical, questioning approach.```

entries.title: Word Lens
Microsoft is testing live translation on Intel and AMD Copilot Plus PCs
entries.snippet: Microsoft has begun testing its live translation feature on Intel and AMD-based Copilot Plus PCs, expanding its availability beyond the initial rollout on Qualcomm-powered devices. The feature, currently accessible to Windows 11 Insiders in the Dev Channel, translates audio from over 44 languages into real-time English subtitles, working with any audio played on the device—whether from online videos, live conferences, or recordings. Supported languages include Spanish, French, Chinese, Russian, Korean, Arabic, and more. In addition to this expansion, Microsoft is enhancing the service on Qualcomm PCs to support translations into Simplified Chinese. This development is part of Microsoft’s broader effort to bring more AI-driven capabilities, such as the Recall feature for memory retrieval, to a wider range of hardware platforms.

entries.title: Otter.ai App Adds French and Spanish Transcription: What You Need to Know
entries.snippet:
Otter.ai has expanded its capabilities by adding real-time transcription support for French and Spanish, in addition to English. The app, available on both Android and iOS, allows users to record and transcribe meetings and conversations directly from their mobile device or through a web interface that integrates with platforms like Zoom, Microsoft Teams, and Google Meet. However, it does not offer translation services, so users must be fluent in the chosen language.

The app is free with a Basic plan offering 300 transcription minutes per month (30 minutes per conversation) and limits to three imported files. The Pro plan, costing $16.99/month or $100 annually, raises these limits to 1200 minutes per month, 90 minutes per conversation, and up to 10 imported files. Business and Enterprise plans are also available for users needing more extensive features. Users can edit transcriptions to correct any errors.

entries.title: Google Translate is bringing real-time translations powered by Gemini to your headphones
entries.snippet:
Google has announced a major update to Google Translate that brings real-time translation powered by its AI model, Gemini, to any pair of headphones with a microphone. Previously limited to Google's Pixel Buds, this capability is now available in beta to users with the Google Translate app in the U.S., Mexico, and India. By tapping the "Live translate" button with headphones paired, users can access live, one-way voice translations supporting over 70 languages. This allows users to engage in conversations, listen to lectures, or watch shows in foreign languages with real-time translation delivered through their headphones.

The update also enhances text translations by leveraging AI to better understand tone, emphasis, idioms, and slang, improving naturalness and accuracy. Currently launched with support for nearly 20 languages, these improvements aim to make translation more intuitive and effective. Additionally, a new tracking feature has been introduced to monitor language learning streaks, similar to Duolingo, encouraging consistent practice. Expansion to iOS and more countries is expected in 2026.

entries.title: All Windows Users Can Now Translate Speech in Real Time
entries.snippet:
Microsoft has announced that its real-time speech translation technology is now available to all Skype users on Windows. This tool allows users to translate conversations almost instantly in seven supported languages: English, Chinese Mandarin, French, German, Italian, Portuguese, and Spanish. Text-to-text translation is also available in over 50 languages. The rollout comes after a gradual introduction that began in October and follows initial demonstrations in 2014. Users can activate the translator by clicking the globe icon in Skype, provided their app is up to date.

Since its launch, Skype Translator has seen significant growth, with call volume increasing by 400%. The most popular language pair to date has been French-to-English. Microsoft's translation services improve continuously through machine learning, which enables the software to enhance its performance over time based on past interactions, allowing more accurate and natural translations.

entries.title: WhatsApp users have been begging for message translations for two long years - and now it's finally here
entries.snippet:
WhatsApp has officially launched its long-awaited message translation feature for Android and iPhone users. Announced by Meta through a blog post, this new tool allows users to translate incoming messages into their preferred language by long-pressing a message and selecting the 'Translate' option. Languages can be downloaded for offline use, and the feature works in group chats and channel updates, not just one-on-one conversations. Importantly, all translations occur on-device, enhancing user privacy.

Initially, the feature supports over 19 languages on iPhone, while Android starts with six languages: English, Spanish, Hindi, Portuguese, Russian, and Arabic. However, Android users gain a unique advantage with exclusive thread translation, which enables automatic, ongoing translation of entire conversations — a convenience not available on iPhones.

This update marks a significant improvement for the platform, addressing user demands that have persisted for over two years. Before now, users relied on third-party apps to translate messages. Meta anticipates that the new feature will help eliminate language barriers and foster deeper global connections through the app. Though small in scope now, the translation capability is expected to expand over time.

uring and translating speech/video) is still limited on macOS compared with enterprise tools. Many workflows rely on system audio capture or browser extensions.
